Course Name: Navigating Your Medical Future Through Self-Authorship
Course Description: Innovation in the world of medicine is fueled by individuals who are inspired by their lived experiences and stimulated by their curiosities. Consciously and unconsciously, our lived experiences impact our decision-making, and through reflection and contextual frameworks, we can curate lives that connect to our values and passions. This course aims to create opportunities for students to understand self-authorship as a beneficial process for personal development. They will self-reflect in a way that encourages purpose-focused career exploration in medicine. This process will enhance their personal ability to make internally focused decisions in their professional pursuits. Students will begin to identify how their personal stories, passions, and intellectual curiosities contribute to their distinctiveness in the medical school application process and beyond. Integrated with frameworks from life-design theory, self-authorship, and career development, this course will help discourage the check-box approach to medicine and encourage utilizing personal experiences as a tool in developing a well-rounded medical school application.

Course Description: Are you ready for 21st-century healthcare? The etiology of disease is often linked to nutrient deficiencies. We'll cover Digestive System Anatomy, Carbohydrates, Dietary Fiber, Lipids, Protein, Water, Vitamins, Minerals, and Nutrient Tracking. We'll also conduct in-class cooking demonstrations to experiment with tasty ways to prepare vegetables. Daily assignments will include keeping personalized food logs to track calories, micronutrients, fiber, and protein intake using Cronometer software. Required Materials: 1.) eTextbook Basic Nutrition by Lori Smolin and Mary Grosvenor, 2.) Digital Gram Food Scale, and 3.) Computer Screen Capture Software

Course Description:
This course will use the process and mindsets of Life Design to help students explore careers and build a network in the fields of biology, healthcare, and molecular sciences, specifically in tue United States. Through life design classwork, guest lectures from alumni and industry experts, alumni networking opportunities, and experiential learning (site visits and networking sessions), students will work to understand their own career and professional interests and motivations, prototype possible career paths, and find their fit within the broader Philadelphia area. The impact of this experiential course will expose students to a company’s culture, day-to-day work life, and unique career paths.
Objectives:
•	Synthesize their experiences, values, skills, and identities into a guiding work view statement.  
•	Apply employer background research to create authentic introductions and prepare insightful questions for site visits.   
•	Design possible lives to ideate unique career paths within the industry.  
•	Practice skills necessary for success within an industry. 
•	Create an effective online presence aligning with industry values and objectives including crafting clear relational accomplishment statements, developing a professional profile, and expanding their network

Course Description: In this seminar course we will discuss the historical context of bias and exclusion in science, read from and discuss the primary literature to understand the science of bias and why it is present and how it has continued to persist across the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields, and identify actionable items to address and overcome these issues.

Course Name: The Microscopic Secret Society Of Bacteria That Rule The World
Course Description: Learn about the Earth’s earliest and most successful branch of life, bacteria! In this 2-week course we will learn about how dependent all life on Earth is on these tiny friends and foes. You will discover microenvironments and evolution. Learn important concepts in microbial ecology that apply to systems as large as planet earth down to the symbiotic bacteria in the human gut (yes bacteria control the air you breathe and your poop!). You will also learn about academic bacteriology research opportunities happening at Hopkins and the greater Maryland area.

Course Name: Biopharma 101: How New Drugs are Discovered, Developed, and Approved
Course Description: This course will focus on the discovery and clinical development of therapeutic drugs and biologics from the perspective of the biopharmaceutical industry. We will discuss the requisite laboratory research that identifies and characterizes molecules that can reach clinical testing in humans, execution of a clinical development plan that includes phase 1, 2, and 3 clinical trials, the generation of clinical evidence that forms the basis for NDA and BLA applications from which pharmaceutical sponsors receive approval from regulatory authorities such as the US FDA.  Ethical conduct in clinical research and the commercial and economic considerations that contribute to decision-making in what drugs for what diseases move forward will be emphasized.

Course Description: Microbes live everywhere around us – in the soil, in our guts, in salt and heat and aridity. How different are the microbes from such diverse environments? How similar are they? Additionally, students will be encouraged to contextualize their laboratory findings in terms of broader themes in cell biology and evolutionary biology. This intersession course welcomes students from all years and majors.

Ancient Philosophy is often associated with geometry, cosmogony, & ethics. But from the 5th century on, we also have a vibrant discourse about concepts of “Generation”, a collective term describing topics like procreation, heredity, embryology.
We will touch upon various issue like “What is Science?”, “Empiricism vs. Imagination”, “Origin of Seed and Embryo”, “Preformation vs. Epigenesis”, “Contribution of Man and Woman to Life” & trace them from antiquity to the modern era.

Course Description:
This course introduces students to field methods in linguistics with a heavy hands-on component. The goal of this course is to become acquainted with the practical and technical skills involved in conducting linguistic fieldwork, with a focus on morphology and syntax. We will also discuss the ethical issues involved in fieldwork and the publicization of fieldwork results. Throughout the course, we will be working with a language consultant who speaks Tamil.

How do linguists build a grammar for a language they don't know? This course introduces students to linguistic fieldwork. Students will be working with a language consultant to gain firsthand experience. Students without a background in linguistics are welcomed.

Course Description: Feminist theory equips us to perceive gender at work in the organisation of literary texts, and to criticise those texts that reproduce oppression in image and narrative. The notoriously transgressive novel American Psycho (1991) seems to call for this kind of reading. Its protagonist is a man whose masculinity consists of extreme violence and utterly degraded consumerism. He can speak only in the language of electronics catalogues, fashion magazines, and unfeeling pornography. But is it possible to see in American Psycho a continuation of the second-wave feminist project? Is the vice-president’s-eye-view of Manhattan a satire, a diagnosis of patriarchy in its purest form? And what does it mean to document, fantasise, or regurgitate the violence at the heart of gender? In this course, we place American Psycho in its historical and aesthetic context by reading it alongside the literary work of Kathy Acker and Virginie Despentes and the polemical theory of Andrea Dworkin. We will see, in their critique and feminist reinvention of forms such as pastiche, assemblage, voice, perspective, and the narrator, new and enduring strategies for the reflexive reading of literature. This course comes with a strong content warning for the graphic representation and autobiographical discussion of sexual violence.
School: Krieger School of Arts and Sciences

Course Description: Fantasy and fantastic science fiction love environmentalist themes. Whether it’s an abundance of mythologically-inspired creatures, quests across diverse landscapes, or veiled allegories of an environmental apocalypse, the fantastic deeply engages the nonhuman world, a fascinating paradox in an age that relies on science to know, make sense of, an address the ecological crisis we’re facing. So what does fantasy offer environmentalist causes? In this course, we’ll explore this question, starting with a brief sojourn into the fantastical nineteenth-century roots of the environmentalist movement in the thick of the Industrial and settler revolutions. Then, we’ll spend the bulk of the class looking at several present-day examples, such as Studio Ghibli’s Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind, the recent animated series Scavenger’s Reign, and the cozy indie game A Short Hike. Students will have the opportunity to discuss a fantastical element from these or the media of their choice in a short final presentation.

Course Description: “It comes as a great shock around the age of 5, 6, or 7 to discover that the flag to which you have pledged allegiance, along with everybody else, has not pledged allegiance to you. It comes as a great shock to see Gary Cooper killing off the Indians, and although you are rooting for Gary Cooper, that the Indians are you.” (James Baldwin, “The American Dream and the American Negro”) This class situates Beyoncé’s genre-bending COWBOY CARTER within a tradition of twentieth-century Black cultural production about the American West. By engaging with music, visual media, film, and a variety of written forms, students will gain a deeper understanding of the role of the West—as a region, idea, and ethos—in African American intellectual history and popular culture. Primary texts may include works by Nat Love (a.k.a. Deadwood Dick), James Baldwin, Ralph Ellison, and Angela Y. Davis, and critical readings will introduce students to the study of the Western and the burgeoning subfield of Beyoncé Studies. The course culminates in a discussion of the two most famous pieces of Black Western media: Quentin Tarantino’s Django Unchained and Beyoncé’s COWBOY CARTER.

Course Description: In this course, we will consider what it means for bodies to be considered “toxic.” We will take up the questions of what, precisely, is “toxicity” and how do we come to know it? We will explore how toxicity comes to be defined, identified, measured, and quantified and identify the ways in which toxicity is sensed, perceived, and imagined.  We will consider the relational aspects of toxicity—how it comes to make or rupture social worlds. Ultimately, this course will familiarize students with anthropological perspectives on environmental toxicity in industrial and post-industrial environments.

Course Description: This course explores clothing choices, dress reforms and their relationships with protest movements across the world. The course asks: What forms do sartorial representations take in spaces of protest? Can we extend the notion of “nonverbal resistance” (Crane,2000) to read the convergence of protest attire with its circulation, perception and production? The course will invite students to examine how protest, textile manufacturing and sartorial choices are embedded within our social worlds. We will read anthropological, literary and visual texts to consider how the sartorial makeup of protest sites shows an intersection of institutions, traditional knowledge and even personal intimacies. Students will familiarise themselves with sartorial spectacles and subversions in resistance movements particularly in the contexts of militancy, gendered labor, displacement and the neoliberal exploitation of garment industries. We will also look at the formation of uneven social identities through sartorial encounters and the contemporary relevance of sartorial mobilisation.

Course Name: China in the World: A History in Objects, 1600-1900
Course Description: This class explores the history of China's global engagement from the 16th to the 19th century through objects that tell its stories. Through lectures and discussions, we'll examine how items like European tapestries, imperial letters, and silkworms reveal the interactions between China and the West. We will delve into intriguing questions, such as why the Manchu emperor sought Western assistance to distribute his open letter and how genetic diseases in Western silkworms impacted the Chinese silk trade.
School: Krieger School of Arts and Sciences

Course Description: In this course, we examine female authors as intellectuals critical for understanding the medieval world. Among such authors are Hildegard of Bingen (1098-1179), who wrote about plants using medical theory; Marie de France (1160-1215), who was among the first women to make a living out of writing; and Christine de Pizan (1364-1431), who wrote the City of Ladies, describing how women were capable of complex reasoning.

Course Description: This course is designed to prepare students with prerequisite concepts and skills needed for AS.110.106 or AS.110.108. Topics include key topics from algebra, the basic library of functions studied in calculus and the characteristics of those functions, including, polynomials, rational functions, algebraic functions, trigonometric functions, exponentials and logarithms.

Course Description: This course is designed to prepare students with the advanced prerequisite concepts and skills needed for AS.110.107 and AS.110.109. This intersession course is for students who have previously earned 3-credit hours of Calculus I with AP credit or by taking AS.110.106 or AS.110.108, and plan to enroll in Calc II in the Spring. Topics include trigonometry, polynomial division, limits, derivatives, integrals, integration by substitution, integration by parts, and introduction to differential equations. The course will also help students recall precalculus knowledge to gain insight into limits, derivatives, indefinite and definite integrals.

Course Description: This course is designed to prepare students with an introduction to concepts and skills needed for AS.110.202. Topics include multivariable functions and their graphs in R^2, R^3, vector arithmetic, dot product, cross product, and vector-valued functions.

Course Name: From Caesar to Cybersecurity: Cryptography Through the Ages
Course Description: Cryptography Through the Ages introduces students to the exciting practice of making and breaking secret codes. Students will begin with simple Caesar Ciphers, learning to encrypt and decrypt messages, as well as the history behind the cipher. They will move through history and more advanced mathematical concepts to learn substitution ciphers, Vigenère ciphers, and multiplicative and affine ciphers. Students will need to put all of their newly acquired knowledge to the test by finishing with public key cryptography and the modern-day RSA cryptosystem.

Course Name: Health Activism in the Digital Age
Course Description: This course explores the rise of health social movements and their role in shaping public health, patient rights, and healthcare policies. Special attention will be given to the impact of technology on health activism, particularly the role of digital platforms, consumer health technologies, and patient-driven innovations. Students will analyze case studies, engage in critical discussions, and develop an understanding of how activism has evolved in the digital age. Students will be expected to participate actively and lead discussions on specific topics.

Mathematical concepts pertinent to AS.171.106 will be introduced and reviewed with motivation by limited assumed physical and mathematical knowledge from AS.171.105, AS.171.101, or AS.171.107. Topics include single-variable calculus, vector algebra, multivariable calculus, and some introduction to complex functions and ordinary differential equations.

Course Name: Review to Preview – General Physics for Biosciences II
Course Description:
This intersession course is intended to prepare students for General Physics II (AS.171.104) for Spring 2025. The students should have already completed General Physics I (AS.171.103, AS.171.101 or earned AP credit) by the end of December 2024 and planning to continue on to General Physics II in 2025. The course will provide a thorough review of foundational topics from Physics I, including vectors and vector fields, forces, energy, dynamics, oscillations and
waves. There will also be a preview of General Physics II material, which will focus on the application of integral calculus to physical problems (Calculus I and II).

Course Description: This course will cover the basic principles of Raman spectroscopy, their applications in characterizing microscale and macroscale materials, visualization and interpretation of Raman spectra. Students will also have the opportunity to perform hands-on experiments in the Raman lab. Topics covered include: Optical methods, inelastic and elastic scattering of light, Raman selection rules, Surface-Enhanced Raman Scattering (SERS), polarization dependence, photoluminescence, etc.

Course Name: Advanced Statistical Methods for Data Analysis
Course Description: Have you ever wondered how someone claims a discovery? How do we measure the masses of particles, determine the effectiveness of a drug, or calculate someone’s credit score? To draw strong, science-based conclusions from data, we must use statistical methods. In this course, you will learn all about probabilities, likelihood functions, hypothesis testing, and neural networks. You will grasp key concepts from statistics and immediately apply them to solve real-world problems.

Course Name: Death from Above:  Weaponized Drones and Persistent Surveillance
Course Description: For all the controversy surrounding the use of drones in domestic and international operations, the ramifications of their deployment are not yet clear. This course explores the theoretical and political implications stemming from the introduction of drones into various geopolitical spaces. Most simply put, we will be asking what it means to project power without vulnerability. More specifically, we will draw from recent scholarship from a variety of fields to analyze different use cases, geographic theaters, and short- and long-term impacts of their deployment. Issues of asymmetry, surveillance, precision, civilians/enemy combatants, vulnerability, chains of command, and agency will be central to our study.

Course Name: US Foreign Policy toward South Asia
Course Description: This course will examine U.S. foreign policy towards South Asia from the period spanning the September 11th terror attacks to the present day. It will introduce students to the major issues in U.S. foreign relations with the South Asia during this period, with particular focus on the nations of India and Pakistan. The course will look critically at the way U.S. foreign policy towards South Asia has developed and evolved, what major influences have shaped that policy, and how past developments have impacted present issues and problems. The course will also consider how approaches the United States has pursued toward the region have related to broader American interests and objectives, such as the non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, stabilizing the region, and managing the rise of an ascendant China.  The Trump Administration's impact on foreign relations with South Asia will also be examined.

Course Name: Gender and Constitutional Politics in Global Perspective
Course Description: Across the world today, in places as diverse as India, Nepal, Chile, Argentina, and the United States, constitutions are being contested, challenged, reinterpreted, or replaced. Some view this as “democratic backsliding,” while others see a resurgence of popular democracy. In many of these cases, the center of the constitutional debates focuses on gender and sexuality, such as abortion, political participation, and bodily autonomy. This course will examine how contests over gender intersect often at the center of constitutional politics and questions over the meaning of democracy. How do contests over gender and sexuality reveal the tensions between majority rule, individual rights, and constitutional limits on state power? Why do contests over gender and sexuality so often seem to come to the forefront of constitutional politics? Exploring examples from numerous countries, we will examine how overtly or silently constitutions reinforce or seek to disrupt existing gender relations.

Course Name: Frontlines of Freedom: Civil Society's Role in the Global Democratic Ecosystem
Course Description: How can civil society promote and defend democracy while authoritarianism is on the rise around the globe? Through both theoretical discussions and practical case studies, students will gain a deep understanding of how global pro-democracy networks operate, the challenges they face, and strategies for resisting authoritarianism. Students will learn strategies for organizing and sustaining democratic movements, with a focus on how international networks of activists operate in hostile environments and the ways they collaborate to counter the influence of autocratic regimes. They will also critically engage with the implications of global democratic backsliding for the health of democracy in the United States. By the end of the course, students will be equipped to engage in global pro-democracy efforts with practical insights into organizing and sustaining democratic movements. The course will be taught by RDI Senior Fellow Felix Maradiaga, a prominent political dissident from Nicaragua with expertise in nonviolent resistance and democracy building strategies.

Course Name: Putting the Public Back in Public Policy: Deliberative Democracy and the Transformative Power of Cit
Course Description: This class is for students who care about the state of our representative democracies. The class begins with an exploration of democratic deficits and the limitations of our current governance structures. Students will be introduced to democratic innovations, the deliberative wave and citizens’ assemblies and asked to consider how to effectively mobilize around such platforms. Seeking practical and replicable practices, we will examine a model for Activated Citizenship and study the ways that participants come together, learn, engage and find their voice. Marshalling evidence-based practices, students will actively engage with a variety of materials, including reports, academic journals and news media. We will conduct cross-cultural comparisons of four citizens’ assemblies including the French Citizens’ Convention for the Climate (2019-2020) as well as the more recent French Citizens’ Convention on the End of Life (2022-23), the Deliberative Committee on Homelessness (2021) in Brussels, The Second Citizens’ Assembly on Democratic Expression (2021-22) in Canada and the Petaluma Fairgrounds Advisory Panel (2023) in the United States. Each Case Study is considered within a carefully designed framework for Citizens’ Assemblies, alongside an analysis of the variables that enhance Activated Citizenship in government-initiated and championed Citizens’ Assemblies. The final class will be a design lab where students will be asked to bring their own understandings and practices to the table, deliberate and create a blueprint for more meaningful and consequential public engagement interventions that mobilize, inspire, and generate a more inclusive and responsive democratic culture.

Course Name: Cultivate a Culture of Connection: Transforming Communities and Civic Participation
Course Description:
With civic engagement in decline and increasing reports of loneliness and disconnection, this course addresses the urgent need to enhance involvement and strengthen connections to support the resilience and vitality of individuals, communities, and democratic systems. Through an interdisciplinary approach, students will explore principles and practices for designing and implementing strategies that foster community networks, support individuals, and empower civic participation.

Combining theoretical frameworks with real-world case studies, this course covers topics such as social capital, grassroots organizing, community development, and the role of technology. Readings will include diverse case studies, analyses, and historical perspectives from leading scholars and practitioners. In interactive discussions and collaborative exercises, students will critically examine the challenges and opportunities involved in building more connected and engaged communities. In the course, participants will explore practical tools for fostering community resilience and enhancing civic participation.

Course Name: The Science of Hearing: Sound, Brain and the World
Course Description: Sounds play a very important role in our everyday lives. From helping us wake up on time every morning, to communicating our deepest thoughts. How is sound processed in the brain? How do we get to assign meaning to sounds? In this course, students will learn about the basic properties of sound, the neurobiology of sound processing, understand how hearing research is implemented in humans and other animals and why it is important. Students will critically read, analyze and discuss research papers. They will be engaged in active discussions, evaluative viewing of a documentary and use the concepts acquired in class to identify dangerous sound levels, and apply this knowledge to improve their daily hearing practices.

Course Description: Psychology is the study of the human psyche, yet unlike many other scientific disciplines, the central object of its study (i.e. the psyche) is unobservable and its existence is still contentious. This raises an important question: is the study of psychology a scientific endeavor? To answer this question, we will first examine what the criteria for accessing scientific validity are, drawing from readings from Karl Popper, Thomas Kuhn, and other philosophers of science. Then we will apply these criteria to subfields of modern psychology to decide if psychology as we know it is science or pseudoscience.

Course Name: Mind Reading 101: The psychology of mental state inference
Course Description: Understanding the minds of other people, or “mind-reading”, is among our most important capacities as a social species. Explaining peoples’ actions in terms of underlying mental states such as beliefs, desires, preferences, and so on often feels obvious, yet at the same time, misunderstandings about the mental lives of others pervade our daily life. How do we form intuitions about what others are thinking and feeling from nonverbal interactions, regardless of whether these intuitions wind up being correct? This intersession course will provide a brief overview of the scientific literature on mind reading and discuss the major theoretical questions that guide ongoing research.

Course Name: The Science of Memory: From Lab to Life
Course Description: Memory is such a dominating component of our day-to-day lives that research into the cognitive systems underlying memory has been and continues to be one of the most well-developed bodies of literature across the cognitive sciences. Course Name: “I Came to Theory Because I was Hurting.” Introduction to Autotheory
Course Description: The ‘story of me’ goes back to the beginning of literary history and is told all around the globe, but the twenty-first century is all about first-person experience and performance. From Marina Abramović’s “The Artist is Present” and Black Mirror’s interactive episode “Bandersnatch” to the breaking of the fourth wall in Fleabag, the imperative of the new century is to be present, immersed, and to touch things directly. This course explores the artistic drive for total absorption and investigates the ethical implications of placing the self at the center of contemporary production. Is self-inscription the same as self-discovery, or is it just narcissism? When fiction and theory encounter first-person narrations and become autofiction and autotheory, do they limit our imagination? Or are they the place where critical thought encounters the affective, embodied domain of lived experience? Can theory be a place of “healing” as bell hooks famously proposed? Or are we stuck with what Anna Kornbluh calls antitheory? Throughout the course, we will ask how these emerging genres interact with old ones and study the specific ways they engage with gender, race, sexuality, displacement, and nationality. By the end of this course, students will be familiar with Karl Ove Knausgaard, Maggie Nelson, Paul Preciado, and other writers, theorists, and filmmakers, assembling an archive of literature, art, media, and theory across the Americas and Europe.

Course Name: Neuro-Theater: Creative Practice in Immersive Storytelling, Emerging Technology, & Worldbuilding
Course Description: This creative practice seminar is offered in conjunction with a Nexus Research Grant on “Neuro-Theater: How Neurotechnology and Artificial Intelligence Can Transform Immersive Media, Interactive Storytelling, and Live Performance.” Students will explore speculative design, worldbuilding, and devised theater as creative practices, with a mix of reading, discussion, and hands-on exercises. We will use Stanislaw Lem’s iconic science fiction novel Solaris (about a sentient planet that can read the brainwaves of mankind) as a source text and springboard for collective imagining. Class meetings will focus on creative research, with discussions of Lem’s novel, screenings of Andrei Tarkovsky’s and Steven Soderbergh’s film adaptations, and readings about how emerging technologies such as wearable neurotechnology can be incorporated into interactive media and live performance to push the boundaries of immersive storytelling. Students will  engage in devised theater compositions and, if time permits, stage brief dramatic scenes inspired by the source texts that incorporate speculative design and world-building elements.

Course Description:
“All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.” — Leo Tolstoy, Anna Karenina.
In this course, we will examine how the family unit is often depicted in literature: the way families are structured and the ways they fracture, the horrors or affection members of the family inflict and bestow on each other, and the way love and obligation differ across families. Our goal is to comb through these narratives for insight and techniques on how to tell our own stories about the family. This is a multigenre class — we will read fiction, nonfiction, and poetry from acclaimed writers like Alice Munro, Dantiel W. Moniz, Julie Otsuka, Bryan Washington, Jennette McCurdy (author of I’m Glad My Mom Died), Bassey Ikpi (author of I’m Lying But I’m Telling The Truth) and Warsan Shire, among others. As we discuss these stories, we will explore the family as a hiding place, unorthodox family arrangements, parent-child relationships, sibling relationships, queerness, found family, and family inheritances that transcend physical objects.

Course Name: Monster Theory: The Monsters We Create and Why
Course Description: This course would examine the ways we create and portray fictional monsters as well as how these monsters enact the cultural rhetoric they emerge from. This would be a look at not only the traditional ways that monsters are used and presented in narrative, but also a dive into how some creators are subverting these tropes to create a new narrative. Questions like "how do monsters engender othering?" "why are monsters more prevalent in times of crises?" and "how do monsters tie into a feminist narrative history?" would be looked into and discussed.

Course Name: The Collage Form: The Image in Writing
Course Description: In Anne Carson's Nox, Carson writes about receiving news of the death of her estranged brother, collaging the few remaining letters and photos she has from him into a massive scroll that becomes the form and text of a book on grief and translation. In Mary Kelly's Post-partum Document, Kelly collects and collages ephemera from the first six years of her son's life, juxtaposing recordings of his first words, soiled diapers, old clothes with her own journal entries, charting both his and her transformation over time. This course seeks to explore how we can go beyond just the written word in our work, and how pairing it with images, ephemera, and other forms of art can enhance our own vision for our projects. What can collage accomplish? How can we best utilize juxtaposition to tell a story? What is the line between art and gimmick? The course will include discussion of collage works and scholarly analysis on such works, as well as in-studio collage time, and culminate in a workshop of students' own short collaged works that play with form, text, and images to tell a story. Works studied may include selections from Nox by Anne Carson, Post-partum Document by Mary Kelly, What It Is by Lynda Barry, Blackouts by Justin Torres, Here Comes Kitty by Danielle Dutton and Richard Kraft, Citizen by Claudia Rankine, Dictee by Theresa Hak Kyung Cha, "White Dialogues" by Bennett Sims, and Sans Soleil (film) by Chris Marker.

Course Name: I laid down/among the tall grass: a Cross-Genre Ecopoetic Exploration
Course Description: How can ecopoetics be used to mirror our interiorities, as well as point to larger waves that mold the outside? In this week (or 2 week) intensive, student’s will engage with texts from Taylor Johnson, Robin Wall Kimmerer, Ariana Benson, Joy Priest, Jenny Erpenbeck, with visuals from BBC’s The Green Planet, among others. Class begins with an opening workshop, and culminates in a second workshop to close the class; every other class will include in-class writing assignments with prompts; each class will have a discussion element. Students will leave the classroom with a deeper appreciation for the natural world and the tools to look both inside and out in their writing, and hopefully, with a touch of green.

Course Name: Self-Care & Storytelling for Public Health Professionals
Course Description:
What role do storytelling and narrative writing play in public health and medicine? What is the importance of self-care for public health professionals? What are the various ways that self-care can look? And how does storytelling play into self-care? This course will explore the answers to all of these questions.
 
In health and medicine, we often turn to authority figures and experts for the answers to problems, whether those be individuals such as doctors or government organizations such as the NIH or CDC. This paradigm often creates a dichotomy between patient and practitioner. What is missing in this paradigm is that patients and community members also have answers—answers that can inform the root causes of health issues as well as public health policy and practice. Storytelling and narrative writing are critical methods for uncovering these answers and for building a rapport among patients, practitioners, and communities.
 
Storytelling is also a powerful tool for self-care and healing, which are necessary ingredients for success in public health professions. This course will give you permission (read: require you!) to engage in daily self-care and reflect on your self-care activities.
 
Classes will include a combination of daily ice breakers, discussions, journaling activities, and a personal health improvement project, all of which will give us an opportunity to reflect on our life experiences and aspirations, help us better understand ourselves and one another, and equip us to be even stronger public health professionals.
 
In addition to being instructive, this class is going to be fun! It will be a safe space to talk about pretty much anything that’s on your mind. This syllabus is not by any means set in stone and will rather be guided by what you wish to discuss and get out of the course.

Course Name: Foraging botanical metaphors: plants and literature in the east and west
Course Description: This two-week course explores the interplay between metaphor, aesthetics, naming, and knowledge through the lens of botany. Students will investigate how our enduring fascination with plants has informed and transformed literature and visual arts across cultures. Through an interdisciplinary approach, we will examine works by naturalists, poets, novelists, and artists to analyze how botanical subjects are perceived, understood, named, and reimagined. The course delves into the power of plant-based metaphors in expressing ideas, compares plant metaphors in Eastern and Western traditions, and explores the relationship between scientific observation and artistic interpretation. Readings will include passages from Michel Foucault, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Emily Dickenson, Natalie Diaz, Li Shizhen, the classical novel Dream of Red Chamber (Honglou meng), and so on. All reading materials will be in English.

Course Name: Experiential Research Lab Travel: Transnational Birthing Justice - Ghana
Course Description: Transnational Birthing Justice: Ghana II is a place-based writing-intensive Experiential Research Lab. In the second part of this course, students will travel to Ghana for 14 days to complete their research. While in Ghana students will partner with international-based public health agencies, The University of Ghana School of Public Health, and Accra-based partners, to utilize their writing, research, and public health skills to develop a framework to address maternal health challenges in Ghana. Students will engage with Ghanaian practitioners focusing on community health to participate in a Hopkins-sponsored community health screening and maternal health kit giveaway to support local individuals. Students will visit three cities, Accra, Kumasi, Cape Coast, and sites like Kakum Rain Forest, and Elmina Slave Dungeon. Students will build a portfolio of writing that will include writing for themselves, social media, community, and scholarly audiences. This class will be co-taught with Tanay Lynn Harris, the co-founder and director of Bloom Collective. During and after their travel students will write to juxtapose their previous research about the maternal health challenges in Ghana. Students will complete their writing portfolios by composing reflections of their semester-long journey, and engagements with Ghanaians, and revise and radically reimagine their research about maternal health challenges in Ghana.

Course Description: This course focuses on a monetary approach to national income determination and the balance of payments. Money and banking, as well as commodity and financial markets, are dealt with under both central banking, as well as alternative monetary regimes. Particular emphasis is placed on currency board systems. Students learn how to properly conduct substantive economic research, utilizing primary data sources, statistical techniques and lessons from economic history. Findings are presented in the form of either memoranda or working papers of publishable quality. Exceptional work may be suitable for publication through the Johns Hopkins Institute for Applied Economics, Global Health, and the Study of Business Enterprise. Advanced excel programming skills are required and students are expected to be pre-screened for research at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.. Bloomberg certification is a requisite.

Course Description: In this 2-credit intersession course, we will explore creative techniques for making visually compelling photographs using smartphone technology. Through photography assignments, demonstrations, and field trips, we will experiment with many photography apps that can be used for manual camera exposure, image adjustments, digital collaging, and other visual effects. We will use Fuji and Canon smartphone printers to make inkjet and polaroid prints of our phone images, as well as use various online platforms to submit course projects. We will also discuss the ethical responsibilities of using smartphones in both private and public spaces and learn how the history of technology has shaped our understanding of art, culture, and everyday life.

Course Name: Baltimore’s Historic Pipe Organs – A Survey and Tour
Course Description: Aptly described by Mozart as “the King of instruments,” pipe organs have taken pride of place in Baltimore’s churches and civic halls since the industrial revolution. This course will provide an overview of organ construction using significant instruments in the city to demonstrate the evolution organ building techniques. Students will hear, examine, and play instruments spanning more than 125 years including an organ built in Baltimore, the first major organ by noted American builder Charles Fisk, and the ‘magnum opus’ of the Schantz Organ Company. No prior keyboard skills are required.
School: Krieger School of Arts and Sciences

Course Name: Go Compose - Your Music, Your Way (music composition for the 21st century)
Course Description: In Go Compose – Your Music, Your Way, you will discover the freedom of creating music that’s uniquely yours. This course offers a supportive environment for students of all skill levels to experiment and compose in a way that works for you. You will learn new composition techniques, explore different styles, and work with professional composers and performers to bring your ideas to life. With personalized feedback and guidance, you’ll create an original composition that will be performed live by a professional musician. Whether you're new to composing or already have musical ideas, this course will provide you with the tools and inspiration to develop and refine your music. At the end of the course, your composition will be performed live. No prior experience is necessary—just your passion for music and creativity.

Course Description: Popular from the late 1940s to the mid-1970s, romance comic books introduced teenagers to the joys and heartache of love. Course Name: Global Immersion: Business in Latin America—Chile
Course Description: This course aims to develop in-depth knowledge of current trends and skills in sustainable innovation. Innovation is at the heart of economic growth and the lives of millions depend on it in developing countries. At the same time, market expansion in these countries have often brought massive changes that threaten the economic and environmental sustainability of the most vulnerable. Both Carey Business School faculty and professors of local universities will provide classes on the history and current status of innovation in business in Chile and their impacts on sustainability. Of particular importance will be the discussion of how private initiatives can deliver successful business opportunities while contributing to local sustainability. Corporate and government organization visits will complement lectures and case studies to assess how businesses are adjusting to changing business landscapes.
School: Carey Business School

Course Description: The purpose of this course is to immerse you in issues and dynamics related to power and politics in organizations. We seek to make power and politics discussable, recognizable, and usable. In other words, this course is designed to fuel learning of concepts that are useful for understanding, analyzing, and harnessing power and political processes. But beyond discovering ways to extend your own power, influence, and political skill, we will also uncover lessons about ways in which power and politics can blind and deceive you, and how you might better navigate situations in which you are up against relatively more powerful people or forces. We will use a range of learning methods including theoretical and business articles, cases, exercises, assessments, and simulations. We will cover a variety of topics ranging from political skills, bases of power and influence, dangers of power, power and change, and leading with power.
School: Carey Business School

Course Description: This course examines site planning, building design, and managing the construction project. The class is divided into two sections. The design section focuses on the conceptualization of the project, and the construction section looks at the management of the implementation of the project. Emphasis is placed on how the selection of materials, equipment, and systems can affect both the function and cost of the building. The course also includes a detailed review of the forms of construction contracts and associated documents commonly used in the industry.
School: Carey Business School

Course Description:
This course will teach students how to design a PCB (printed circuit board) in KiCAD and how to translate Arduino sketches to (truly micro) microcontrollers like the ATtiny that can be tightly
integrated onto a PCB. This course is particularly valuable to engineers who are looking to translate a bulky prototype into a tightly integrated, mass-producible solution. The course will cover all aspects of

Course Name: Introduction to Scientific Programming in Python
Course Description: This is an introductory course in programming python for students in the mathematical sciences. Short tutorial lectures will be followed by problem solving sessions. Topics emphasized will include linear algebra problems, ordinary differential equations and optimization. Also a particular interest  will be given to practical machine learning problems (classification, regression and clustering).

Course Name: Energy 101: Introduction to the Business and Policy of the US Energy Industry
Course Description: This three-day intersession class will be a high-level overview of the US energy industry. We will focus on electricity, natural gas, oil, renewables and other forms of energy. We will discuss how each commodity is produced and traded from the perspective of the producer, the distributor, and the end user. The class will provide an overview of the technologies that convert energy into useful work, as well as the market, regulatory, and policy structures that influence investment in production, delivery, and consumption of electricity and natural gas. The goal is to provide a basis for further study, and to motivate students to consider a career in the industry. There are no prerequisites or textbooks, and the class is open to all. The course will be a mix of economics, basic engineering, financial mathematics, and sociology. Energy use, production and efficiency at the Homewood campus will be discussed. Instructors are Carl Liggio and David Yaffe.

Course Description: Since its inception, the petroleum industry has fundamentally changed the energy landscape of the world.  This course will cover an introduction to the major aspects of the petroleum industry.   We will discuss the industry fundamentals, its evolution, the markets served, the processes employed, the impact of petroleum on geopolitics, and regulation and oversight.  We will close with a discussion around the energy transition and the expected impacts that will arise as a result of the world's ambition to decarbonize energy systems.

School: Whiting School of Engineering

Course Description: This three-day intersession class will examine the role of financial markets as the world looks to shift to a more environmentally sustainable global system and fund the trillions of dollars of necessary to enable this shift. The class will begin with a brief overview of the capital markets, the current energy mix in the United States, and how new energy projects are evaluated and funded. Students will be asked to review, analyze and discuss investment opportunities focusing on key risks, economic return, and environmental impact. The goal of the course is to understand how the global financial market, one of man's most powerful tools, is currently financing change and how it can be more efficiently leveraged to address global environmental issues. Day three will focus on the legal issues of project and tax equity financing, mergers and acquisitions, renewable energy development and the international and domestic energy sector overall.

School: Whiting School of Engineering

Course Name: Energy 104: Electricity Markets, Trading, and Risk Management
Course Description:
This two-day intersession class introduces the student to complex electricity markets through live in-class trading simulations. The class is taught by an energy industry portfolio trader who has 12 years of experience trading electricity, natural gas, options, ancillary services, and transmission rights.
The course alternates between lectures and electricity market games that illustrate the underlying drivers of the evolution of power markets. This allows for a more intuitive understanding of how markets have evolved into their current structure.   Lectures on the second day will focus on the current nodal structure and the key players in these markets - load serving entities, generators, utilities, and the Independent System Operator. 
Significant in-class participation and group work is required. A senior guest speaker will provide his perspective on these markets followed by Q&A.   
All majors are encouraged to take this class and there are no prerequisites.  In-class work requires basic math to be done in excel.  There is a short assignment required to be completed before the first session that will acquaint the student with excel.  A laptop with working WiFi connection is required to be brought to the class.

Course Name: Basic Intellectual Property Law for Scientists and Engineers:  Patents, Copyrights and Trademarks
Course Description: The course will outline the basics of intellectual property laws with an emphasis on practical aspects of protection of IP for scientists and engineers.  Most of the course will cover the basics of patent law, but introductions will also be given to trademarks and copyrights.  Specific problems in the areas of biotechnology, computer science and the Internet will also be highlighted.  It is hoped that the attendees will obtain a basic understanding of how intellectual property is protected.  No prior legal background is required.

Course Name: Statistical Foundations of Neural Data Science
Course Description: "Statistical Foundations of Neural Data Science" is a three-week intensive course meticulously designed to guide participants through the multifaceted world of statistical analysis and its application to neural data. The course embarks with foundational sessions on data types and advanced visualization techniques, ensuring participants gain proficiency in understanding data distributions and representing them effectively. Progressing to Week 2, the focus shifts to intermediate statistical concepts, encompassing critical topics such as probability, hypothesis testing, and the intricacies of correlation. As the course culminates in Week 3, participants delve into the realm of signal analysis, familiarizing themselves with Fourier transforms, wavelets, and advanced filtering techniques. Each session is crafted with a clear progression from theoretical understanding to hands-on projects, offering learners the opportunity to apply their knowledge in real-time scenarios. This curriculum promises a blend of essential statistical principles and cutting-edge analytical methods, preparing students to excel in the dynamic field of neural data science. Background Knowledge: Very Basic Probability and Statistics, Some Linear Algebra, Python. A short session for Python will be held for those who are not familiar with it.

Course Description: This course offers an in-depth exploration of pharmacogenomics (PGx) and its critical role in personalized medicine. Designed for students with no prior background in genetics or pharmacology, this 2-week intensive course will cover foundational concepts and advanced applications of PGx. Students will be introduced to the basic concepts of clinical pharmacology and learn about the genetic factors influencing drug efficacy and toxicity. The course includes practical case studies on application of PGx in various therapeutic areas, such as cardiology, oncology, psychiatry, pain management, and infectious disease. Through interactive lectures, discussions on social and ethical implications, and hands-on activities, students will gain the skills necessary to understand and interpret PGx findings, and to critically think about the challenges and opportunities in personalized medicine.

Course Name: Mechanistic and Data-Driven Insights into Disease
Course Description: This course will explore computational methods to quantify underlying mechanisms and predict prognosis of various biological diseases. The course will cover mathematical modeling of signaling cascades, agent-based simulation of multicell systems, and deep learning to glean hidden features in biological data. Students will work in teams over the course to explore a real- world disease using the simulation techniques we learn in class and will have the opportunity to present their results to expert guest researchers in the field.

Course Name: Introduction to Spatial Omics Data Analysis
Course Description:
Single-cell sequencing allowed scientists to understand cellular heterogeneity within tissues. However, this process dissociates the cells, losing their context information. The advent of spatial omics enabled the comprehension of tissue structure and characterization of spatial patterns, leading to discoveries in health and disease. This course will introduce students to the field of spatial omics analysis. During the first lectures, students will learn about the history of spatial omics, how the data is collected, the different technologies (barcode-based methods,
 
fluorescence in situ hybridization), and the different data types available (transcriptomics, proteomics, chromatin accessibility). Following this, students will learn about specific data analysis methods and will apply them to real datasets. Topics include data preprocessing and exploration, clustering, identification of spatially variable genes, cell-type deconvolution, subcellular analysis, multimodal analysis, tissue alignment, and cell-type colocalization. The grades will be based on the in-class coding activities related to the method taught and on a final project in which students will be free to choose the data to analyze and the tools to use. The course will teach methods written in R and Python programming languages, but no experience in programming is required.

Course Name: Introduction to the Adaptive Immune System
Course Description: In this course, we will provide a basic understanding of the immune system with a focus on the adaptive immune response. An emphasis will be placed on the immune system’s ability to respond to a diversity of pathogens (specificity) and to remember previous encounters with pathogens (memory). Dysfunctional adaptive immune responses in the context of immunodeficiencies and autoimmunity will also be discussed.

Course Description: RNA-based therapeutics have emerged as a new class of drugs to address previously "undruggable" targets through conventional drug modalities. This course will cover various types of RNA-based therapeutics with a focus on mRNA, siRNA, and antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs). By examining modes of action, recent clinical and pre-clinical development, challenges in delivery and immune toxicity, and potential solutions, this course will provide a comprehensive look at each type of RNA therapeutic.

Course Description:
Deep learning (DL) has become a widely recognized and powerful approach in machine
learning, excelling in supervised tasks by learning complex patterns within the data. In this
course, students will be introduced to the basics of neural networks, coding with PyTorch, and
how DL can be applied to spatial transcriptomics—a cutting-edge field that combines gene
expression data with spatial information to provide insights into tissue architecture and
function. The class will feature a mix of lectures and hands-on coding assignments, including a
final project where students will apply a DL technique to a real-world spatial transcriptomics
dataset. While we will cover Git and GitHub briefly, a strong foundation in Python is
recommended for success in this course.

Course Name: Tissue-Engineered Models of the Blood-Brain Barrier
Course Description: Blood vessels in the brain form a specialized and multicellular interface called the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Critically, the BBB maintains brain tissue health, while its dysfunction is associated with neurological dysfunction. Modeling the BBB is key to understanding and identifying interventions for these diseases and, to do so, tissue engineering, stem cell technology, and microfluidic techniques are all leveraged. This course will introduce students to engineering strategies for modeling the blood-brain barrier, with focus on application of models to study the human brain during health and disease.

Course Description: Synthetic biology is the practice of re-engineering organisms to perform a useful task. The goal of our course is to expose students to the relatively novel field of synthetic biology through (1) lectures on genetic design techniques and tools, (2) hardware design for biological measurement, and (3) modeling of genetic circuits using ODEs. Students will present a project at the end of this course synthesizing everything they have learned.

Course Name: Introduction to Cancer Biology and Therapies
Course Description: This course covers an introduction to immunology and how the immune system plays a key role in regulating cancer. We will discuss how cancer arises, the interplay between the immune system and cancer, and ultimately the outgrowth and establishment of metastases. Then we will explore the past, current, and future (in development) cancer therapies.

Course Description: The class will cover the basics of immunology and bioresponse. Course Name: Data4BrainDynamics: Leveraging Data Science and Math for Studying the Brain
Course Description: Recent advances in computational tools are an asset for computational neuroscience research and are a key step to improving understanding of how the brain encodes behavior. The main goals of this course are to introduce students to various mathematical models in neuroscience; to present the great potential of computation in studying the brain, and to introduce exciting real-world challenges in neuroscience research. This course is also helpful for students who are interested in improving and expanding their programming skills as it will introduce advanced Python visualization tools and unique neural-analysis Python packages. The course will combine theoretical lectures about various computational neuroscience aspects, Python hands-on tutorials, and interactive scientific activities (e.g., virtual neuro-escape room, outdoor competition, etc.). Over the course duration, the students will work in groups of 3 on computational neuroscience projects, which they will present towards the end of the course. Some math and programming background is highly recommended though not required. If you wish to take this course but are not sure about your background knowledge or have any other questions please reach out to the instructor.

Course Name: Biological Impacts of Static Magnetic Fields
Course Description: With burgeoning technologies, the effects of magnetic fields on human health is becoming an increasing interest. This course will delve into the current understanding of the bioeffects of static magnetic fields and their underlying physical and biological mechanisms. It will then discuss those effects in the context of biological systems (nervous, immune, etc.) and their validity in detecting and treating diseases (cancer, diabetes, etc.) according to published literature.

Course Name: Neuroengineering Device Design: Build Your Own Neural Stimulator

Students will learn and have the opprotunity to apply skills such as microcontroller fundamentals, printed circuit board (PCB) design and assembly, and CAD modeling with 3D printing. Using these techniques, students will work in pairs to design, build, and demo their own functional neural stimulator prototypes.

Course Description: Algebraic statistics is a recent direction of research that leverages abstract algebra (i.e. commutative algebra and algebraic geometry) to address statistical problems. This intersession course will provide a self-contained and brief introduction to the field of algebraic statistics, its application to aspects of causal inference and biomedical data science. The course starts with a glossary review/preview of needed vocabularies and tools from probability, statistics, commutative algebra and algebraic geometry, along with some handy computational tools. We will not go into great details of mathematical proofs, but only the notion and major consequences; we will go over proof sketches of important theorems as needed. Then we focus on case studies on how algebraic techniques could be used for (1) identification problem and (2) experiment design. Background in programming, linear algebra and prob/stats required.

Course Description: Humans navigate and interact with the 3D world by perceiving their surroundings, engaging with others, acting, and exploring that allows them to form mental models to simulate and explore the world. Similar to humans, the machine (like AI system) can simulate the world through machine imagination. "Machine Imagination" is a course that delves into how artificial intelligence can simulate creative and imaginative processes traditionally associated with human thought.  In this course, I will first connect machine imagination to theories of human imagination and mental models from a cognitive science perspective. Then, students will explore machine imagination from computer science perspectives, through learning the advanced topics in generative models, such as variational autoencoders and diffusion models with vivid examples. The course covers how these technologies enable machines to generate visual content, and how they aid decision-making in the real world.

This intersession course is designed to introduce students to the exciting world of APL and provide a unique opportunity to network with professionals and learn about internship opportunities.

Course Name: The PostElection Reshaping of Climate Commitments
Course Description: 2024 was a landmark year for pivotal elections around the world, with new leaders elected in most major global economies.  This course, led by a JHU alumnus and senior government advisor on climate finance, will explore how a new president in the White House, as well as other new leaders around the world, is likely to impact climate commitments and the flows of finance required for their delivery.

We will consider current problems and identify solutions that may yield greater equity in these contexts. We will study how stereotypes, behavior, structural systems, and organizational cultures contribute to inequity. We will provide an introduction to the concept of intersectionality. Course Name: Tech and Entrepreneurship in the Bay Area
Course Description: This course will be a hands on, immersive experience that combines JHU’s Life Design Framework, in partnership with employers and alumni in Big Tech and Startups in the Bay Area to help students explore careers and build a network in the fields of technology and entrepreneurship. Students will get curious and imagine possible lives through the lens of different career profiles in tech, (i.e software developers, information security analysts, computer programmers, web developers, and digital designers, etc). Through life design classwork, guest lectures from alumni and industry experts, ranging from fin-tech to med-tech, alumni networking opportunities, and experiential learning (site visits and networking sessions), students will work to understand their own career and professional interests and motivations and possible career paths, and find their fit within the broader Bay Area tech ecosystem.

Course Name: B'More: Storytelling for Humanity: Baltimore Narratives
Course Description: This course explores storytelling's role in shaping our understanding of what it means to be human, particularly within the context of Baltimore. Students will explore how narratives influence perceptions, build empathy, and drive social change. Through hands-on workshops and classroom engagement, they'll learn to craft compelling stories that showcase the diverse experiences and resilience of Baltimore's residents, promoting a richer appreciation for the city's diverse cultural heritage.
